title: Electric-car sales have fallen for the first time on record — and China's subsidy cut may be to blame
text:
The Chinese government's decision to reduce state subsidies for electric cars and other vehicles with alternative driving systems appears to be having its first consequences: In July, global electric-car sales fell for the first time in history.

Monthly sales worldwide fell by 14%, to about 128,000 plug-in cars, according to a report cited in Bloomberg.

Sales have declined primarily in China and North America, while Europe has seen an increase.

Though China is the largest market and producer of electric cars, the government reduced subsidies for new purchases of electric cars on June 26.

This measure was designed to encourage automakers to focus on product innovation. China's slowing economy may also have reduced willingness to buy EVs, according to Bloomberg.

Electric cars are still in a niche market, but the declining demand for gas-guzzlers indicates that the future of mobility lies in alternative fuels.

According to Bloomberg, global sales of electric vehicles increased by 35% in the first seven months of the year. The full-year forecast for 2019 is estimated at 2.9 million newly registered EVs.

"Unsurprisingly, the growth momentum halted in July amid subsidy cuts," a Bernstein analyst was quoted as saying. "Despite expected short-term weakness in 2H19, we continue to be positive on long-term EV demand."
